channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Georgia and the Carolinas, Ian Is Forecast to Cause Heavy Rain and Strong Winds
item.description: Weakened but still dangerous, the tropical storm is expected to produce strong winds and heavy rains as it moves north to Georgia, the Carolinas and Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: Technicians monitoring Hurricane Ian inside the National Response Coordination Center at the Federal Emergency Management Agency headquarters in Washington, DC. on Wednesday.

item.title: Britain’s Gamble on Tax Cuts has Economists Warning of Past Mistakes
item.description: The International Monetary Fund is just one of the many voices that have criticized a plan to cut rates for high earners.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s new prime minister, has staked her fledgling government on a once-in-a-generation package of tax cuts and deregulation meant to energize the economy.

item.title: Stocks Drop as Focus Shifts Back to a Potential Recession
item.description: Investors are anticipating a global recession as central bankers take a hard line against inflation, looking to slow the economy by raising interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: NATO Pledges ‘Determined Response’ to Nord Stream Pipeline Leaks
item.description: The alliance said the damage was “the result of deliberate, reckless, and irresponsible acts of sabotage.”
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Swedish Coast Guard/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A photo from the Swedish Coast Guard showing gas leaking from the Nord Stream 1 pipeline under the Baltic Sea on Wednesday.

item.title: Even as Oil Prices Ease, U.S. Keeps Tapping Strategic Reserve
item.description: The administration’s move has brought down gasoline prices. Some experts say continued withdrawals could test the nation’s energy security.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Adrees Latif/Reuters
item.media:description: The Bryan Mound Strategic Petroleum Reserve in Freeport, Texas, one of the sites where the United States stockpiles oil.

item.title: New Infectious Threats Are Coming. The US Probably Won’t Contain Them.
item.description: The coronavirus revealed flaws in the nation’s pandemic plans. The spread of monkeypox shows that the problems remain deeply entrenched.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Brynn Anderson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Flags representing Americans who died of Covid-19, a work by artist Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg, on the National Mall last year.

item.title: China’s ‘Absurd’ Covid Propaganda Stirs Rebellion
item.description: The use of propaganda in the country has been on overdrive in the pandemic, with some Chinese citizens arguing the language has bordered on “nonsense.”
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Beijing last week. In some cases, Chinese citizens are required to get a coronavirus test three times a week.

item.title: Physician Burnout Has Reached Distressing Levels, New Research Finds
item.description: Nearly two-thirds of doctors are experiencing at least one symptom of burnout, a huge increase from before the pandemic. But the situation is not irreparable, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Charles Rex Arbogast/Associated Press
item.media:description: Burnout, in medical literature, is defined by increased emotional exhaustion, a more distant approach to the job and a declining sense of personal accomplishment.

item.title: Coolio, ‘Gangsta’s Paradise’ Rapper, Dies at 59
item.description: From a bookish, asthmatic child to mainstream hitmaker, the West Coast M.C. charted a distinctive path to hip-hop stardom.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Paul Bergen/Redferns, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Coolio in 1995. The rapper’s song “Gangsta’s Paradise” hit No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 chart that year.

item.title: David Geffen Hall, Notoriously Jinxed, Is Reborn Again
item.description: David Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic’s Lincoln Center home, is reopening after a $550 million renovation aimed at breaking its acoustic curse — and adding a dash of glamour.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: The new hall features seats surrounding the stage and behind the players.

item.title: A Pioneering Orchestra Boss Had ‘Unfinished Business,’ So She Returned
item.description: Deborah Borda led the New York Philharmonic in the 1990s, and was frustrated by its subpar hall. After a 17-year run in Los Angeles, she “finally saw a path forward,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Deborah Borda, a major figure in the orchestra world, returned to the New York Philharmonic, which she led in the 1990s, in 2017 to help usher it in to a radically rebuilt home.

item.title: Timeline: The Long, Long Journey to a New David Geffen Hall
item.description: After decades of failed attempts, the New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center are hoping that the new $550 million renovation has finally fixed the hall.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Carl T. Gosset Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: The hall, originally called Philharmonic Hall, was the first part of Lincoln Center to open.

item.title: The Syncopated Sounds of Old San Juan Hill at the New Geffen Hall
item.description: Etienne Charles’s composition for the reopening of the hall honors the Afro-diasporic musical heritage of the neighborhood razed to build Lincoln Center.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Josefina Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trumpet player and composer Etienne Charles, whose work for the New York Philharmonic, “San Juan Hill,” will help inaugurate the newly renovated David Geffen Hall.

item.title: Despite Iran’s Efforts to Block Internet, Technology Has Helped Fuel Outrage
item.description: Online, Iranians engage in a world their leaders don’t want them to see.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Iranian demonstrators taking to the streets of the capital, Tehran, during a protest days after a young woman, Mahsa Amini, died in police custody after she was accused of violating the country’s headscarf law.

item.title: How McKinsey Got Into the Business of Addiction
item.description: The consulting firm’s work with opioid makers is well known, but for decades McKinsey worked with Big Tobacco and has also advised Juul, the e-cigarette company.
item.dc:creator: Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: McKinsey & Company in New York City. The firm’s work with opioid makers is well known, but its work with cigarette and vaping companies has escaped public scrutiny.

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Is Out of Prison and Trying to Defeat Bolsonaro
item.description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is trying to cap a stunning political comeback by defeating the incumbent Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil’s elections on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. da Silva has taken to comparing himself to Nelson Mandela, Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr., political prisoners who expanded their movements after they were freed.

item.title: On Eve of Election, Bolsonaro’s Party Attacks Brazil’s Voting Systems
item.description: Four days before Brazilians vote, President Jair Bolsonaro’s political party formally claimed, without evidence, that government employees could alter ballots.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil at a rally on Saturday.

item.title: Aaron Judge Hits 61st Home Run Tying Roger Maris
item.description: In one of the greatest seasons in major league history, Judge, the Yankees outfielder, has matched Maris’s American League record for home runs in a single season.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Judge’s 61st home run of the 2022 season came in the seventh inning of Wednesday’s game against the Toronto Blue Jays.

item.title: Aaron Judge of Yankees Reacts to Hitting 61st Home Run
item.description: Aaron Judge went seven games without a home run and admitted the chase for No. 61 wore on him. With one swing, he matched Roger Maris’s record. And now he’s ready for more.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Judge shared a moment with Manager Aaron Boone after circling the bases for his 61st home run of the season.

item.title: Roger Maris Would be ‘Tickled to Death’ to be Matched by Aaron Judge
item.description: Aaron Judge tied Roger Maris’s American League record with his 61st home run of the season, and Maris’s former teammate Bobby Richardson sees many parallels.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Judge, a master of understatement, briefly acknowledged the crowd in Toronto as he was cheered for his 61st home run of the season.

item.title: The Polish Folk Art Pajaki Makes an Unexpected Comeback
item.description: The practice of making pajaki, the Polish folk art created to honor the earth, finds an unexpected revival.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:credit: Ayesha Kazim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karolina Merska, a Polish artist who lives in London, makes and sells pajaki for about $600 each and has been running pajaki workshops from her art studio in East London for the past five years.

item.title: The Fetterman-Oz Race Is No Piece of Cake
item.description: The Fetterman-Oz race is one of this fall’s big political dramas.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: Ron DeSantis’s Race Problem
item.description: Ron DeSantis has targeted Black people, Black power and Black history.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

item.title: The Most Important Question About Addiction
item.description: Why do people do drugs?
item.dc:creator: Maia Szalavitz
item.media:credit: Teun Voeten/Panos Pictures, via Red​ux

item.title: I Escaped Poverty, but Hunger Still Haunts Me
item.description: Food was scarce when I was growing up, so I ate all I could when I had the chance.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Cooper
item.media:credit: Antoine Cossé

item.title: One of the Hottest Trends in the World of Investing Is a Sham
item.description: Just because a company meets E.S.G. criteria doesn’t mean it’s a good corporate citizen.
item.dc:creator: Hans Taparia
item.media:credit: Jeff Hutchens/Getty Images

item.title: Dating Is Broken. Is Going Retro the Answer?
item.description: Old-fashioned courtship is having a moment.
item.dc:creator: Michal Leibowitz
item.media:credit: Derek Abella

item.title: In New York, NIMBYism Finally Outstays Its Welcome
item.description: Political momentum is growing for efforts to build more housing, fast.
item.dc:creator: Mara Gay
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times
item.media:description: Homes in the Throgs Neck neighborhood of New York.

item.title: In Retirement, You May Not Need to Spend So Much
item.description: As people age, they get less satisfaction from travel, cars, clothes and appliances.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images via Getty Images

item.title: What to Know About Ian and Climate Change
item.description: We have the latest on Hurricane Ian, another storm to gather strength with frightening speed.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt, Claire Moses and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tampa, Fla., as Hurricane Ian hit.

item.title: One Man Flees Putin’s Draft
item.description: Kirill, a 24-year-old from the Moscow region, is taking desperate measures to avoid being conscripted to fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Will Reid, Michael Benoist, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Irakli Gedenidze/Reuters
item.media:description: A crossing station on Monday in Georgia, on the border with Russia. Since the draft was announced, more than 200,000 Russians have fled their country.

item.title: The Run-Up: American Evangelicalism and the Midterm Elections
item.description: A new class of American evangelical leaders is shaking up the Republican Party — and raising the stakes of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein/For The Washington Post via Getty Images

item.title: Pete Souza’s Obama Book Cuts Obama Out of the Picture
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.category: The West Wing and Beyond: What I Saw Inside the Presidency (Book)

item.title: The Last Days of an Outback Town Where Every Breath Can Be Toxic
item.description: The town of Wittenoom, ruined by asbestos mining, will be wiped off the face of the earth. But first the government had to remove those who wanted to stay.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Once a symbol of economic prosperity, Wittenoom, Australia, is now a ghost town, polluted by decades of asbestos mining.

item.title: In Arizona Governor’s Race, a Democrat Runs on Abortion
item.description: Katie Hobbs has struggled to compete against Republican Kari Lake, who is running on border security and election fraud conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy and Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arizona Democratic candidate for governor Katie Hobbs in Tempe this week.

item.title: Mexico Named Deadliest Country for Environmental Activists
item.description: A new report from the watchdog group Global Witness found that 54 land rights activists were killed in Mexico last year, the most of any country.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Gutierrez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mourners attending the burial service for the Indigenous rights leader Tomas Rojo in the Yaqui Indigenous community Vicam, in the Mexican state of Sonora, in July 2021.

item.title: The Gottmans’ New Book Tries to Fix Your Marriage In 7 Days
item.description: The renowned love researchers have been happily wed for decades. Would following the advice in their new book improve my own relationship?
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Marta Monteiro

item.title: The Challenges of Dating With Chronic Illness
item.description: Deciding if and how to share health information can leave daters on a tightrope between vulnerability and vigilance.
item.dc:creator: Fortesa Latifi
item.media:credit: Peter Garritano for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Joseph Kibler, 33, started online dating, he experimented with how best to share information about his health.

item.title: 7 Questions to Strengthen Your Relationship
item.description: After two years of tumult, these essential conversations can help couples talk about what’s working, what’s not and where the relationship is headed.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Clifford Prince King for The New York Times

item.title: How to Reconnect With Your Partner After Having Kids
item.description: Don’t wait for the most convenient time to rebuild intimacy. You’ll be waiting a long time.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: How A.D.H.D. Can Affect Your Relationships
item.description: The symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder can push couples to their breaking point, but there is hope for those willing to seek help.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Lucy Jones

item.title: ‘Bold Enough to Go Full-Tilt’: Gabby Beans Is Playing to the Balcony
item.description: The actress, a Tony nominee for “The Skin of Our Teeth,” is bringing her sharp eye for comedy to Atlantic Theater Company’s production of “I’m Revolting.”
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez
item.media:credit: Desmond Picotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabby Beans said Eartha Kitt was among her inspirations. “She had a way of relating to the audience, and it’s really special to see someone hold everyone’s attention with their presence.”

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
